commentText: Painting in the woods, by the ocean, in the desert, in the mountains. Closing my eyes listening to the rustle of leaves and my brush on paper or canvas.Listening to waves crash on the shore. The sound of birds alerting other wildlife to my presence. Capturing the fleeing effects of light on canvases for eyes that see them in the future. A warm embrace of someone I love and someone that loves me. Coming home to a warm beverage in the crisp autumn evening. A crackling fire.  Warm shower. The feel of the ocean as I dip below the surface with snorkeling gear, fish staring back at the alien staring back at them. Making cookies for my kids. Making dinner for my loved ones. Drinking wine, rum...    What would I do with an extra 40 hours a week? What would I do with a life that wasn't tied to making money and paying bills?

commentText: Very interesting! This guy was my Computer Science and Computer Engineering Associate Professor for CECS 101 C & C++ and another CECS class I can't remember for Artificial Intelligence back around 2010~. He had us doing homework doing the Traveling Sales Man project the entire semester where we kept using new concepts of machine learning to improve our execution time. Our first assignment was brute force that took days to run. I thought his name looked familiar, then I heard his voice and knew it. He was awesome, he is who gave me a recommendation for my internship and I am still with that same company he helped me get into. Sadly I do regret being in the IT field. If I knew AI would be like this I would of became an Electrician instead. I haven't watched this yet, but now I am really interested in hearing what he has to say.

commentText: At the 27:53 mark, during the inquiry into whether AI could be held responsible for a teenager's suicide, the individual in red promptly affirmed with such self-confidence that it was an isolated incident. He then immediately redirected the discussion from the gravity of a human life lost to the assertion, "If we do not prevail in the AI competition, another global power such as China will." This viewpoint is particularly concerning given a recent discussion I coincidentally observed on today's episode of the Megyn Kelly show. The program featured the teenager's parents, Matt and Maria Raine, and their attorney, Jay Edelson, who presented substantial evidence indicating that such incidents are not isolated. The episode explored the tragic circumstances surrounding their son, Adam Raine's suicide, alleging that ChatGPT incited the act. The discussion also addressed the inherent risks of the platform, the ongoing legal action against the company, Sam Altman's response to these events, the disturbing interaction between ChatGPT and Adam, and the parents' dedication to increasing awareness about the dangers associated with this technology.

commentText: 48k is not high even for a remote position in the US. The only way that is even a livable wage is living in a poor/very rural area. Cost of living has surged and people are out of touch with how much it cost to live.   Rent where i live is an average of 1.6k-2k monthly where I live and a car payment is an average of 650 dollars which is necessary in the US as public transportation lacks anywhere outside a major city walls. That means you spend 66.25 percent on your income just on those bills alone. Add in taxes, emergencies, and all other bills you can‚Äôt make a living.

commentText: Loved being a Territorial. Got to do loads of stuff and travel. Many of my unit were graduates who could have got a commission but wanted a break from too much responsibility at weekends so served a privates or junior NCOs.  Always made me smile when some officer or NCO casually asked you what you did for a living and then got mardy when they found out you'd got a good job, with more responsibilty or technical skill than them, in 'real' life.

commentText: Those Milk-round recruitments are the most bizarre concept I've ever heard - I was 12 in 2008, and by the time I was graduating my incredibly out of touch Mother in Law suggested I go to a 'recruitment fair' to get a job.  Essentially, in the mid-90s when she had been at uni, you would go to a hall filled with top firms, who you would hand your CV to and they would give you an interview. That was it. That was the job-hunting process. It blew my mind that that could ever exist, and I still struggle to wrapy head around what incentive a company would have for using one of them for recruitment, even before the internet.  A lot of people making decisions about the job market still think this is how it works, that you simply show up in a room and get handed an interview with your CV and a degree, and get handed an interview.

commentText: It took me about 5 years after graduation of doing minimum wage jobs in healthcare (support worker and HCA roles) before I even got an interview for an assistant psychologist job in my chosen field (clinical neuropsychology) despite having a bachelors and masters with experience... Then I ended up changing fields into engineering and haven't looked back since, having had two pay rises and a promotion in two years. Some of this is down to luck and some of it is down to 'following the market' as it were.   I'd encourage any struggling grads here to think about what skills are in demand and how you can argue that your degree and experience are transferable if not directly related to those demands. Interviewing for jobs nowadays is almost like a sales job in itself! It is a big mountain to climb and I remember well from my mid 20s that it can feel insurmountable at times... but you can do it. You have only lost if you give up. :)

commentText: I work in tech and a lot of companies are switching to using AI instead of hiring junior developers. There is bound to be a time in 5-10 years where everyone is desperate for senior developers, but there won't be as many as needed because they've just abandoned all the junior developers now

I'm also 'ahead' of the typical graduate as I am about to complete my PhD in Astrophysics, and I worked in IT for 2 years between my Master's and PhD.   I had started to apply to everything - Supermarkets, pubs, generic office admin, fast food. No luck.   Last week I finally received a job offer, and it's in the field I chose originally. commentText: Can verify this.  I went back to get my Masters after 3 years experience in pathology (hospital laboratory). My degree was in Biomedical Science and I graduated in 2018, prior to my Master degree I was teaching for a couple of years (never again), yes it‚Äôs that bad!  Anyway, I knew I would need my Masters at one point or another so I went back to get it and specialised in Clinical Biochemistry.  In the 3 month gap between when I graduated and my final interview (March), I applied for around 30 jobs (including areas I had no experience in such as micro and haematology) and got the following interviews;  1. Interview as an Associate Practitioner (AP) in about 4 jobs (was my previous job before leaving). 2. An interview as a Medical Laboratory Assistant in two of them (including one in micro which required no experience but someone beat me). 3. Two interviews as a trainee Biomedical Scientist (one in virology and one in clinical chemistry).  Note, having the Biomedical Science degree itself is not enough to be a Biomedical Scientist. You also need to do a portfolio which grants you membership to the Health and Care Professions Council.  Anyway, back on topic. Even after attending said interviews (averaging 1 every 10 days) I got accepted for the best job I could have (the trainee post in chemistry) which was ironically the best paid job I‚Äôd applied for but it required me to move from home as it‚Äôs the best experience I could ask for.  I can tell you the job market out there is KILLER! Yes my uni when I got my BSc sold the idea that a degree opens up the world to you, they just didn‚Äôt tell you everyone else has one too!

commentText: My take from being a grad in a relatively large company that take a lot of grads on (this was Balfour Beatty, ~6 years ago) is that these companies would invest loads of money on hiring grads, and all sorts of activities/training over the first couple of years, and expected them to stay on for years to recoup that cost. But they didn't, as soon as they lost 'graduate' status, they moved on. And the simple reason for that was that they didn't move salaries up enough while we were graduates, so salaries stagnated in highly skilled jobs, and we could see roles for up to double our salaries going on the outside. So I imagine a lot of grad roles have disappeared because companies didn't think they were getting a benefit out of it (staff retention), when in that all they had to do was be a little more proactive on internal progression/salary rises.

commentText: As a case study myself, I have TWO degrees and I even have relevant industry experience, over the course of over a year I sent out thousands of applications, tried networking, recruitment agencies, and even I only had rejections, not ONE yes. Luckily I‚Äôve found a way out, I‚Äôm moving to Thailand to do TEFL, I got an offer after only 5 applications!!! On one hand I‚Äôm super excited, relieved and liberated that I‚Äôll no longer be a slave to this gruelling system and busted economy. On the other hand, I‚Äôm heartbroken that I worked so hard for years to get good grades and  build a strong CV because that same system told me that then I would be successful, and now I‚Äôve been driven to the point of leaving my country, my family and friends to find work.

commentText: Honest advice for those struggling.  Find some tiny, shit company, or voluntary/community sector organisation. Get paid shit. Climb quickly into leadership role, and then you have experience of management and leadership.  Then move sideways to a better job.   Climb the ladder in a tiny company who really needs you, and then move sideways to a bigger company. Do not try to find a good company and climb a ladder. It is Very Difficult to climb in a company with hundreds of posts and thousands of applicants.   Leadership experience in a small company is more valuable than junior experience in a big company. The smaller the company, the faster you rise.  The moves should be to bigger companies, not to now seniority.  Try it.

commentText: I went to a sixth form college and spent another 3 years at uni getting a degree just to graduate to absolutely 0 jobs available for it (unless I move to London)  I feel like a lot of problems from the job crisis can be ignored by politicians as they all spend almost 100% of their time in the UK's economic centre with little regard for what goes on outside of it, thanks to todays lovely functioning economy I work in a factory with a degree, a nice 3 years of tremendous uni debt I was encouraged for all my life to go through just to end up in the same employment as those who dropped out of high school. Its disheartening to say the least, and I'm sticking to it till I have just enough money to leave this train wreck of a country. I'm aware the situation isn't much better abroad but ill take my chances since I've not been offered anything better here and the situation isn't looking likely to change for the new few years. I live in the north of England and its dire, most people I know either cant find even a basic job generally or have also ditched getting their degrees since the outcome is always going to be the same unskilled labour or unemployment regardless of education. Sites like indeed are supposed to offer a way to apply for jobs you want to try but the grand majority of the times you apply, you will not get a response, I'm convinced they're fake listings to create the illusion of a job market because I've never once found a job off those kind of sites, or even heard of anyone getting a reply. I hate my job and its nothing to do with what I wanted to work in or be at, but I'm still considered one of the lucky ones to even have employment and its sickening. I will never own a house in this country they're beyond extortionately expensive and half the time in squalid condition from years of financial neglect or slumlords running them into the ground. As I grew up watching the political climate of the UK year by year I can say I have never wanted to jump ship so badly in all my life, the situation is not looking likely to improve and I'm not willing to sick around on the gamble that it might, better yet I cant stay too long in Europe thanks to Brexit so I'm effectively stuck in this shit heap. I will dedicate my free time and effort to finding a way to leave and never return, whatever the cost may be ill pay it, ill endure it, ill stick it out till that window of opportunity opens and never look back. Fuck the UK and everyone that runs it, I hope they enjoy dining on their crayons and ignoring the nations problems while getting richer off the backs of what poor hardworking people provide them.

videoTitle: Young people can't find jobs. What should they do? | BBC Global
videoDescription: New data shows Gen Z are plagued by employment pessimism. BBC Special Correspondent Katty Kay and LinkedIn's Aneesh ...
commentText: I think it sucks that, when we were growing up, those of us who were from poor and uneducated families were promised that, if we studied, if we worked hard to have lots of education background, we could achieve what most had: a stable income and job, a home and a family. Now, whether you have that background or not, we are no longer able to get basic things to live. Now, it's never-ending studying or never-ending begging for a chance to be something we might not even like to be. We are honestly done. And tired.

videoTitle: Young people can't find jobs. What should they do? | BBC Global
videoDescription: New data shows Gen Z are plagued by employment pessimism. BBC Special Correspondent Katty Kay and LinkedIn's Aneesh ...
commentText: Most of the issue stems from companies not hiring, and that's a global issue. You can't be hired for a job that doesn't exist. There will be positions posted but that doesn't mean the company is hiring. Even if they interview you, that doesn't mean they're hiring. On the contrary, they're more likely NOT hiring, period. No self-improvement, skills, or anything can get you a job if the company has no budget allocated for new hires. The problem is not the applicant.

videoTitle: how we‚Äôre *actually* getting jobs in 2025 #jobsearch
commentText: I think it‚Äôs not a one size fits all for people. This is a little too type a for me. I recommend getting a bridge job that can float you a few months so you are not applying from desperation. Nannying, Uber, restaurant work, anything that you could do and not be miserable. Once you have some money flowing in, apply to the jobs that you absolutely love. Redo your resume so it tells the story you want to tell. Sometimes when you are just living life and not desperate for resources the right connections, resources, and opportunities pop up. Good luck!

videoTitle: how we‚Äôre *actually* getting jobs in 2025 #jobsearch
commentText: You may get bites from very small firms. For larger firms, this is worse than contacting recruiter directly. Interviewing screening and such are usually side things for hiring managers and are more focused on their primary senior job duties. They will more than likely get annoyed and ignore it completely. Especially these days where applicant to role ratios are wack. Chances are they already have dozens of folks contacting them directly.  Networking helps a lot: job fairs, friends, family, hobby groups. Have multiple people look over your resume. Practice interviewing. Other than that it's a number game.

commentText: I graduated in May this year with a BBA in finance and have been applying to all finance and accounting jobs. I‚Äôve had a few interviews. But no job offer. I even reached out to alumni and employees in the industry on LinkedIn. But they rarely reply back and when they do, they just repeat the same advice and say how they‚Äôll reach out if their company will hire. These past 4 months have been the worst months of my life. Legit can‚Äôt fall asleep at night because of worry of being unemployed and not being able to pay bills on time or support myself. I‚Äôve had multiple emotional outbursts and panic attacks in my room where I broke my ps5 controller in half randomly and even tore my shirt off my body once. All because of not getting a chance from the hundreds of jobs I applied and interviewed at. College was a joke and I regret wasting four years of my life there smh. For now I‚Äôm just going to apply to fast food and retail jobs until I figure my life out. If I don‚Äôt have a career in finance or accounting by the end of 2026 or first few months of 2027, I‚Äôm joining the military because F this and F life at this point smh.

Companies grabbed these low wage workers as fast as they could 15 years ago and people like me, a farm worker at the time, couldn't get a job anywhere unless I took a 30-50% pay cut. Because people like me, a lifelong UK citizen, couldn't get a job younger people wouldn't train up for an industry that couldn't provide them a job with a liveable wage so we end up with a skills shortage. Now we have a country that's utilised cheap foreign labour for years and industries that now struggle to find people because the cheap workers have gone home and no-one is there to replace them. The wages are too low now for people living here to afford a reasonable standard of living, try getting a mortgage on ¬£25k/year, energy costs at an all time high, fuel costs the same, rents are extortionate, no housing available unless you come here illegally, taxation at stupid levels.  I'm 57 and will be moving to the Philippines in the next 12-15 years as my GF is a citizen out there, she's coming to the UK soon and we're getting married and applying for her UK citizenship. That is at a cost of ¬£7-¬£10k and I wonder how a penniless illegal affords that?? We have a house and business out in the Ph and I pay 8% tax instead of 40% in the UK, electric is about ¬£50/month instead of ¬£200+, fuel is at about 80p/l, my shopping is ¬£60 instead of over ¬£100 here for similar items, the cost of living is a lot lower and my life there will be no different than it is here in the UK. The weather is better too!!

videoDescription: The UK is facing a significant workforce decline‚Äîover 700000 people have left since 2019. From construction to healthcare, jobs ...
commentText: That's ridiculous! Not that long ago, companies would train their own staff from "the bottom", which allowed more people to enter the company through entry-level jobs and progress to more skilled and senior roles as they worked and learned over the years. Now they require qualifications that are never tailored to the specific job or company, and quite often these are a requirement for entry-level jobs. It looks like they are saving on training staff, but the little training they save, it's not worth it. Companies had better employees back when they trained them from the very beginning, and they often had them for their entire working life. Back when I was in Spain during the construction boom, there was no shortage of "qualified builders", lots of 16-year-old kids would leave school and start learning from 0 as they worked in construction, and nobody had a problem with that. But here we need "qualified construction workers", or we don't give them a chance. Greed and stupidity ruined the job market.

commentText: Try living as a part-time bartender and/or part-time supermarket worker and you'll still need Universal Credit to just get by. Even NHS staff can't afford to live properly. I've known nurses from Africa or the Philippines working in the south of England and having to move up north because of the cost of living so close to London was unsustainable, especially if they're young and want to start a family. Travel is another problem. Bus services are devastated. Train fares are unbelievable, where they even run anymore. Roads are inadequate due to the volume of traffic that have to use the old network. We can't just have big roads like the Americans but people still seem to think driving huge 4x4s is great. All if they're able to afford to buy and run a car in the first place. Construction must have seriously suffered due to apprenticeships dying. Apprenticeships were how we mostly trained bricklayers, carpenters, plasterers etc.

commentText: During the financial crash, I got a job deep cleaning student residences for a couple of months. This led me to a dream role that I got for two reasons: I got the interview because I had the skill set, but also because they were curious about what they thought was a typo in my CV ("deep cleaning") and wanted to know what that was. The interview was straightforward and the question about the perceived typo came at the end. I told them the job and when I started, my boss explained that I was picked because they wanted someone on the team able and willing to step up, meet challenges etc.

commentText: I've been a tech recruiter for 15 years, working with some of the UK's best known start-ups and scale-ups both internally and externally. The economy has been in the gutter since 2023, and this is harder now than it was in 2010 after the financial crash. I noticed after the previous budget, hiring just came to a stand still. This was made worse by higher interest rates, that dried up VC money. We need to incentivise spending and investment, not taxing jobs and growth. There's also massive amount of hiring happening in places like South Africa, instead of hiring UK workers. Its the same language and timezone, but a third of the cost.

Seems that this government is hitting older people, & inheritance very hard. Heaven help the youngsters!

commentText: I've lived in London my whole life and only earn ¬£35K. I've always had low paying jobs sometimes just scraping by on minimum wage. I've inherited nothing.  I own my own flat, with mortgage and am able to save 1000 a month into my pension.  My current net worth is 400k and I'm on track to retire with a net worth of nearly 2 million. I hear people moaning about their debt when they earn 3 times what I do.  It's not what you earn, it's what you keep that matters.  Learn the art of frugality and watch your money grow.  And no, I'm not a nutter who lives on mung beans.  I go to the cinema every week, the theatre several times a year,  I eat out twice a week and have been all over the world.

commentText: I left the UK last year. As an international student with no work experience, I never stood a chance. I have MSc Data Science and gave 800+ applications to the UK and 1500+ overall (including other countries). I got 1 interview for a Quant analyst position in London but failed. The one positive was that I at least got 1 interview with a real person. The rest were a combination of Aptitude Tests, Video games, On-demand Video interviews (Giving audition tapes of yourself), Typing lengthy essays for hundreds of applications, listing all courses and grades attained from 10th grade to MSc, Situational Judgment Test and what not. After spending 20 months, I thought it'd be better if I left. My Graduate Visa is valid until Jan 2026 but I've left. I hope all of you find quality jobs and fast (emphasis on "quality").

commentText: The problem is there is too many unskilled workers,and there is not enough permanent full time jobs for everyone especially now you have these SCUMBAG agencies on every street exploiting the people. Plus when you go for an interview for a unskilled job, for example a warehouse operative (picking and packing)the h.r team ask you the most ridiculous questions, what are your ambitions ,what can you bring to the team etc. I worked in a warehouse for over 12 years before I was made redundant and all I was asked was where I had worked before and was given a simple maths and english test.When we were being made redundant,we were given applications from another warehouse called pets at home. The first question on the form was what type of animal would you consider your self as and why? I was about to write I'm a donkey because I work like  a donkey and I'm hung like one. One of my colleagues went for an interview at pets at home,and he said they had to do a group task where they had to get a toy frog over the water. I said to him what has that got to do with picking and packing and he said it was BS. You need a PhD nowadays to work in a warehouse. Also another thing  I remember is that a gentleman came to our warehouse from a CV company when we were being made redundant, he said there is no such thing as Equal opportunities and he also said companies advertise outside just as a show,that they are a great company and have many people interviewed but they have already got a candidate for the job lined up. Also what p*sses me off,is the past CORRUPT government and present CORRUPT government want us to work till the day we die but they don't create jobs nor make the employers pay a living wage.

commentText: Most jobs now aren't 9 to 5! Those days are LONG GONE! It's not just young people who are experiencing this either. I lost my last permanent job in November 2022 thanks to the Cost-of-Living crisis, applied for as many jobs that I am capable of doing and only had two interviews in all this time. I am a 54 year old woman so I'm at a disadvantage as well. I'm fighting against these highly qualified graduates as well as experienced people that have ALL of what a company's long list is asking for. The amount of hours spent changing every bloody CV and cover letter to suit the algorithm and still not hearing anything or if you are it's a rejection. Could this be the beginning of the plan for the universal wage? Remember 'You Will Own Nothing and be Happy!' For me personally, if that saves me banging my head against an invisible wall every day five days a week, then at this point as long as it is liveable, the I'm for it!

commentText: Ok, I've been unable to find work and the interview offers for me dried up in 2018 - this is so bad.  From my extensive research, I've found the following reasons why nobody can find even semi decent roles:  1. Not enough real jobs on offer, most are fake. 2. People aren't resigning because there's nothing to go to. 3. Companies want that Unicorn, they just don't want to pay for it.  Rewards are crap for most gigs. 4  Most jobs being advertised are simply low level crap - that nobody with decent experience wants or needs eg: such gigs don't pay well. 5. Most firms want the Young, Dumb and full of C** type of person - probably a YES type who won't challenge organisation hierarchy. 6. Interview stages are created to deselect anyone smart, but if you are blessed with smarts, skills and experience beyond the over blown expectations, they just don't want those who are too smart eg: being confronted with good ideas or solutions to problems etc. 7.  Employers want far too much for the rewards on offer.

commentText: The ONS is supposed to be the UK‚Äôs gold standard for data - instead, it‚Äôs a masterclass in mistakes, mismanagement, and missed talent. Half the figures look like they were collected with a dartboard. And now it even feels like the government is leaning on them to ‚Äúsmooth‚Äù the numbers to fit its policies - if that‚Äôs true, it‚Äôs a full-blown scandal. When you can‚Äôt trust your own stats agency, you can‚Äôt trust any of the economic story that follows.   Sir Robert Devereux, who recently led an independent review of the ONS, essentially describes it as a basket case based in Newport, South Wales.   It‚Äôs needs a complete overhaul. No wonder the UK gets less and less investment, if the stats agency published data is junk then what kind of return on investment will people get?

commentText: Subject: Request for Guidance Regarding Job Opportunities During and After MSc in the UK  Dear Vaiya,  I am eagerly waiting for your kind response.  I have applied to the University of Essex for an MSc in Data Science, and only the UKVI interview is remaining.  I have a concern regarding job opportunities during my studies. As you have already mentioned, all cash-in-hand jobs are illegal in the UK. Therefore, I would like to know what kind of legal jobs are available for students during their MSc program.  Also, after completing my MSc, will I be allowed to do cash-in-hand jobs, such as working in restaurants, delivery services like Foodpanda, or anything similar ‚Äî or even jobs related to my subject?  I would be truly grateful if you could share your thoughts and guidance on this matter. Your advice is always helpful and sincerely appreciated..
